Gray-Scott partial differential equation system¶

Augustin, Neiro, van der Plas

The Gray-Scott PDE is a an example of a reaction diffusion system, i.e. a systems of PDEs that combine linear diffusion with nonlinear interactions. Gray and Scott formulated their model in 1983 as follows

\(u_t = \epsilon_1 \Delta u - u v^2 + F(1 - u)\)

\(v_t = \epsilon_2 \Delta v + u v^2 - (k+F)v\)

class GrayScottPDE.GrayScott(N, u0=None, v0=None)[source]¶

Text

n_outputs()[source]¶

Returns the number of outputs this model has. The default is 1.

n_parameters()[source]¶

Return the dimension of the parameter vector. The Gray-Scott model has two parameters F and k

simulate(parameters, times)[source]¶

Simulate the Gray-Scott PDE system with the finite difference method

Parameters

  • parameters – a two-dimensional parameter vector [F, k]

  • times – time-points where the model is simulated, t0 = 0

Returns

simulated values of the PDE system [u, v]
